stem: The school nurse is conducting health screenings for middle school students. Based on the documentation in the Tanner Stage Assessment Log, match each finding to the correct gender and sequence.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Student A (Female, 10y/o): Noted small breast buds (thelarche). Parent states her daughter has become 'very moody' lately. 
Student B (Male, 12y/o): Noted enlargement of the testes and changes in the texture of the scrotal skin. 
Nurse's Goal: Education on normal pubertal progression.

tabs.content:

tabs.title: Medical History
tabs.content: Both students are average-risk and meet height/weight percentiles.

rows.text: First physical sign: Breast bud development (Thelarche)
First physical sign: Testicular enlargement and scrotal changes
Occurs roughly 2 years after the beginning of breast development
Appearance of pubic hair and axillary hair

rationale.correct: In females (c1), the first sign is breast budding (r1), with menarche (menstruation) usually occurring 2 years later (r3). In males (c2), the first sign is testicular enlargement (r2). Both genders develop pubic and axillary hair as part of the normal sequence (r4).
clinicalPearls: Thelarche is usually the very first sign of puberty in girls (ages 8-10).
Testicular enlargement is the first sign in boys (ages 9-14).
Menarche is a LATE sign of puberty.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking that a period is the first sign of puberty.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'Buds before Blood'. Breast development always precedes menarche.
